document.docAuthor: Maake, Pholoshi A., Gon, Ofer & Swartz, Ernst R.
document.masterDocTitle: Descriptions of three new species of Marcusenius Gill, 1862 (Teleostei: Mormyridae) from South Africa and Mozambique

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Descriptions of three new species of Marcusenius Gill, 1862 (Teleostei: Mormyridae) from South Africa and Mozambique

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Gnathonemus macrolepidotus :
Gilchrist & Thompson 1913
: 330
â€“331, Tete, Lower Zambezi, Mozambique .
Gnathonemus pongolensis

, fig. 6 .

Marcusenius pongolensis

: 103
;

subSubSection.paragraph:
Holotype .
ANSP 54950, 172.5 mm SL; Pongola River at Paulpietersburg district, South Africa , KwaZulu-Natal; not examined.

Material examined. Limpopo River system : SAIAB 188291, 11: 111â€“193 mm SL, Olifants River, below iron bridge, after Mogologolo village. SAIAB 188303, 4: 115â€“147 mm SL, Olifants River, above Loskop Dam in Aventuur, bridge on dirt road. SAIAB 188302, 20: 55â€“150 mm SL, Groot Letaba River, Broederstroom drift about 10 km from (south) of Tzaneen. SAIAB 188289, 24: 59â€“183 mm SL, Matlabas River, on road R 510 bridge towards Thabazimbi.

Incomati River system : SAIAB 188297, 13: 46â€“136 mm SL, Crocodile River, below N 4 bridge at Matsulu village. SAIAB 188300, 4: 129â€“189 mm SL, Omnia farm dam, Kopmeiden. SAIAB 54448, 12: 49â€“118 mm SL, Sabie River, above Hazyview. SAIAB 188280, 2: 77â€“107 mm SL, Sabie River at Hoxani area below dam. SAIAB 188279, 5: 61â€“158 mm SL, Sabie River, Sabana tributary at the back of the Sabie Adventures. SAIAB 188293, 2: 52â€“53 mm SL, Sabie River, Marite. SAIAB 188304, 11: 82â€“136 mm SL, Sand River.

Nkomati River system : SAIAB 69893, 2: 65.8â€“78.8 mm SL, Phophonyane River, Ntfonjeni Road. SAIAB 69907, 3: 113â€“252 mm SL, Mlumati River, Driekoppies Dam. SAIAB 69949, 7: 39.0â€“ 73.5 mm SL, Nyonyane River, Sisa Ranch.

Pongola River system
: SAIAB 79148, 5: 115.6â€“176.5 mm SL, Pongola River , bridge at road connecting Ndumo with Kosi Bay. SAIAB 188277, 2: 129â€“140 mm SL, Sitilo River, below bridge on N 2 road to Jozini. SAIAB 188296, 16: 79â€“165 mm SL, Pongola River on R 33 road to Paulpietersburg.

Kosi River system : SAIAB 88637, 2, Nkanini stream, below bridge just outside Manguzi on road to Mozambique . SAIAB 88633, 11: 98.8â€“147.7 mm SL, Mahlampane River, at Manguze village below bridge. SAIAB 88615, 11: 61.7â€“178.3 mm SL, Siyadla River, below the bridge just about one metre down and above the bridge.

Remarks. The measurements and meristic data of
Kramer et al. ( 2007 )
â€™s
M. pongolensis
were not always in agreement with our data (
Table 10
), probably due to the inclusion of the Mhlatuze and Nseleni rivers as a southern population of
M. pongolensis
. Since these populations are now recognised as a new species,
M. caudisquamatus
, a new diagnosis for
M. pongolensis
is necessary.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 10. Basic statistics for morphological characters of
Marcusenius pongolensis .
See Table 1 for characters definitions.

tr.th: * Measurements taken from Kramer et al. (2007)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis and comparison.
Marcusenius pongolensis
is distinguished from other species in its more slender body (elongated, smaller body depth), with pD ( 37.1â€“39.8 % SL), pA ( 40.8â€“42.2 % SL) and LA ( 19.5â€“21.9 % SL) (
Table 10
), all shorter and non-overlapping with
M. krameri
(
Table 8
),
M. caudisquamatus
(
Table 5
) and
M. lucombesi
(
Table 9
). Total vertebrae ranges between 42â€“43 vs 44 in other species; posterior total gill rakers (GRt) 13â€“14 vs 15 and 17 in
M. caudisquamtus
and
M. krameri
, respectively (
Table 6
). Lateral line scales 70â€“73 .
Table 7
provides the range for counts of dorsal and anal fin rays, and circum-peduncular scales in
M. pongolensis , M. krameri , M. caudisquamatus
and
M. lucombesi
. Dorsal fin situated about three fourths of standard length from snout. Colour in life of
M. pongolensis
ranges from a homogeneous medium brown to grey-brown with yellowish to golden sheen, underside lighter, body has darker blotches on sides with yellowish fins (
Fig. 2
a). These diagnostic characters agree with those mentioned in
Kramer et al. ( 2007 )
for the holotype of
M. pongolensis
.
Marcusenius pongolensis
is considered closest to
M. macrolepidotus
based on phylogenetic analyses of the mitochondrial cyt b dataset (
Fig. 4
), and significant divergence from
M. krameri
,
M. caudisquamatus
and
M. lucombesi
(Table 2 ).

Electric organ discharge. Detailed in
Kramer et al. ( 2007 )
.

Distribution.
Kramer et al. ( 2007 )
presumed that
M. pongolensis
was absent from the Limpopo River system. However,
M. pongolensis
was found in small numbers in the Olifants, Groot Letaba, and Matlabas rivers (
Fig. 1
).
Marcusenius pongolensis
therefore occurs from the tropical sections of the Limpopo River system in the north to the Kosi River system in the south.

Biology and ecology. The biology and ecology of
M. pongolensis
is not well understood, but populations from an oligotrophic impoundment in Swaziland matured within the first year, at an estimated minimum length of 134 and 119 mm SL for males and females, respectively (
Booth & Khumalo 2010
).
